abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows; Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is substantial; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. A number of useful lessons can be learned from
            Pakistan's experience with bank restructuring and
            privatization including the following: 1. NCB reforms could
            not be carried out without strong government's support
            and commitment. 2. Public sector banks must undergo cost
            restructuring before privatization to bring their
            cost/income ratios in line with private banks.  3. In order
            to secure a good price for a bank sale, the bank must be
            recapitalized so that it is able to meet the minimum capital
            adequacy requirement.  4. Downsizing requires bank
            management to identify excess manpower in the labor force.
            5. A formulaic instead of subjective approach should be used
            to minimize contention, send signals to stakeholders (staff,
            unions, government officials and politicians) about the
            intent to change the culture, and ease the legal process. 6.
            The stock of NPLs must be dealt with through major
            amendments to loan recovery laws and implementation of
            government-induced recovery drives.  7. The government must
            bring in professional management teams from outside to
            restructure and turn around the failed banks.  8. For
            privatization to succeed, the government should avoid
            unrealistic timelines, conduct the sale transparently, lay
            out clear road maps, launch targeted road shows, and
            establish a track record to widen investor interest. 9.
            Restructuring of failed banks is costly but is necessary.
            The high costs reflect the cumulative costs of
            mis-governance and poor management.
